title: Cracking the Realtime AI Java code with Deepak Kumar of Doc-E
description: In this week's session of Realtime Java and AI, Aaron and Mary sit down with Deepak Kumar of Doc-E, the creator of Planet Cassandra's (Discord) chatbot. Listen in to hear Deepak's perspectives on AI and its impact on DevRel.

technical audience many a times that could be incorrect yes right ultimately so so so far you know technical questions what we had to do on top of llms is build this layer of expert feedback and what we have done essentially is we are using AI as an assistant that means let ai go and write the first draft of an answer and then give space to support or subject matter experts to go and edit oh right hey you did a good job yeah right just just work with docky and after let's say 25 questions you will see it act as if it's there as a team member answering all questions for you that's very cool yeah answering questions but then it's the power of generative AI where we not only answer questions but we also started uncovering the developer pain points as to why are developers asking these questions again and again yeah and that took us in a very interesting space where I think we are uh yet to have a lot of tools to help Advocates is to uncover the voice of the community what is it that you know users are struggling with yeah that's right and what we were able to accomplish is after seeing let's say hundreds or thousands of questions over different channels like let's say discourse stack Overflow Discord or slack come up with a report and say hey here are the top five pain points your developers are struggling with and here is how you can fix it you can go create a content that exactly addresses the pain point or you can go create a better ux because your ux is is something which is like the biggest barrier to adoption yeah so uh essentially you know it's a slippery slope support uh leads to advocacy and once we precisely know where our developers are struggling we can precisely create content to address those gaps and you know just as one thing leads to another finally it chanced upon us that this whole developer relations task is around educating users is letting the world know that hey here is a new way of solving this problem yeah and what I have observed
